conclusion: An ideal gas of a definite quality undergoes the ABCDA cycle as shown in the figure, where P1, P2, V1, and V2 are known quantities. It is given that the temperature at state A is T0.
The cycle follows path ABCDA. Points A, B, C, and D form a rectangle in the P-V plane.
We know temperature at state A is T₀.
For an ideal gas, the equation of state is PV = nRT, where P is pressure, V is volume, n is number of moles (constant in this problem), R is the gas constant, and T is temperature.
To find temperature at any state, we can use: T = PV/(nR).
Substituting the value of nR from step 1: T_B = P₂V₁/(P₁V₁/T₀)

The temperature at state B is higher than at state A by a factor of P₂/P₁, which makes physical sense as we moved vertically up the P-V diagram (increasing pressure at constant volume), which would increase the temperature proportionally to the pressure increase.
The temperature in state B is (P₂/P₁) × T₀
